Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Bringing Digital Data Management Training Into Methods Courses (November 18-22 & January 11-15)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Developing appropriate methods of data preservation and sharing is essential for establishing pathways for public access to the data and findings from federally funded research. This project trains its research community in appropriate methods of data management. The modules that the project develops will be freely available to members of the scientific research community as well as to the public, and would be instrumental to faculty developing methods curricula.

The American Anthropological Association (AAA) will produce instructional materials to help a new generation of anthropologists ensure their digital data are ready for digital deposit and made available for future use. Protecting personally identifiable data is important, but anonymizing years of data records after the fact is a lengthy and expensive process. Incorporating necessary data protections ahead of time shortens the time to making these data publicly accessible, fulfills researchers? ethical obligations, and is more cost-effective. By training anthropologists how to accommodate digital archiving requirements into research design, AAA can help anthropologists realize wider availability of the data for their own and others? use. Broader availability of these data can showcase the ways that anthropological research contributes to advancing scientific knowledge and helps solve human problems. Materials generated from the grant will be freely available at the AAA?s website to add to research methods training courses, professional development seminars, workshops, short-courses or certificate programs in research methods across the sciences. The grant will also benefit textbook authors and qualitative software developers, thus maximizing the impact of the award.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The federal government makes a significant investment in anthropological research, research that advances understanding of the human condition through innovative, rigorously designed, and systematically observed investigations in archaeology, biological anthropology, linguistic anthropology, and cultural anthropology. Increasingly, the data records produced by anthropological research take one of many digital forms, and there is considerable public benefit to planning from the outset about how these digital data records will be appropriately managed.

This workshop series resulted in an improved set of educational materials available for graduate courses in each of the main subfields, and enhancing opportunities for research design and implementation at every stage of graduate education. The course materials will be used as well in research methods taught in closely related fields including Art, Asian Studies, Biology, Digital Media, Education, Food Security, Genetics, Information Science, Latin American Studies, Library Science, Linguistics, Museum Studies, Native American Studies, Primatology, Public Health, and Women’s and Gender Studies.

The AAA published the modules on its website’s Learn and Teach—Methods section, using a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International license (http://www.americananthro.org/LearnAndTeach/Landing.aspx?ItemNumber=20641&navItemNumber=20708).  The project also collated a set of publicly available data management plans from awards recently made to anthropology research projects, primarily from the National Science Foundation and National Endowment for the Humanities, as well as information about where to locate DMPs and information about writing them. These resources are posted along with the modules.

 The modules’ availability was publicized widely, through our Association’s Anthropology News [https://secure.americananthro.org/eWeb/AN/AN_SeptOct2016.pdf], through a press release, distributed more than 600 U.S. college and university anthropology departments and 1,500 interested individuals and organizations including the higher education press. And through our social media presence, the association has also posted notifications about the modules to reach about 72,000 followers. The association also provided information to 120 university and commercial presses that publish books and journals in the anthropology field and regularly exhibit at the Annual Meeting, as well as specifically notifying 20 anthropology methods textbook authors and editors. At the Congress of Humanities and Social Sciences, Calgary, May-June 2016, Jeremy Geelen of the Canadian Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council presented a project summary. We have scheduled a roundtable panel discussion about the project and the modules at the 2016 Annual Meeting in Minneapolis (November 16-20, 2016).
